refnamediv.refpurpose: linked lists that can be iterated in one direction

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The GSList structure and its associated functions provide a standard singly-linked list data structure.

Each element in the list contains a piece of data, together with a pointer which links to the next element in the list. Using this pointer it is possible to move through the list in one direction only (unlike the double-linked lists, which allow movement in both directions).
List elements are allocated from the slice allocator, which is more efficient than allocating elements individually.
Note that most of the GSList functions expect to be passed a pointer to the first element in the list. The functions which insert elements return the new start of the list, which may have changed.
There is no function to create a GSList. NULL is considered to be the empty list so you simply set a GSList* to NULL.
To add elements, use g_slist_append(), g_slist_prepend(), g_slist_insert() and g_slist_insert_sorted().
To find elements in the list use g_slist_last(), g_slist_next(), g_slist_nth(), g_slist_nth_data(), g_slist_find() and g_slist_find_custom().
To find the index of an element use g_slist_position() and g_slist_index().
To call a function for each element in the list use g_slist_foreach().
To free the entire list, use g_slist_free().

refsect2.title: g_slist_alloc ()
refsect2.para: Allocates space for one GSList element. It is called by the g_slist_append(), g_slist_prepend(), g_slist_insert() and g_slist_insert_sorted() functions and so is rarely used on its own.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: a pointer to the newly-allocated GSList element.

refsect2.title: g_slist_append ()
refsect2.para: Adds a new element on to the end of the list.
The return value is the new start of the list, which may have changed, so make sure you store the new value.

Note that g_slist_append() has to traverse the entire list to find the end, which is inefficient when adding multiple elements. A common idiom to avoid the inefficiency is to prepend the elements and reverse the list when all elements have been added.

entry.para: the data for the new element

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the new start of the GSList

refsect2.title: g_slist_prepend ()
refsect2.para: Adds a new element on to the start of the list.
The return value is the new start of the list, which may have changed, so make sure you store the new value.

entry.para: the data for the new element

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the new start of the GSList

refsect2.title: g_slist_insert ()
refsect2.programlisting: GSList * g_slist_insert (GSList *list, gpointer data, gint position);
refsect2.para: Inserts a new element into the list at the given position.

entry.para: the data for the new element
the position to insert the element. If this is negative, or is larger than the number of elements in the list, the new element is added on to the end of the list.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the new start of the GSList

refsect2.title: g_slist_insert_before ()
refsect2.para: Inserts a node before sibling containing data .

entry.para: data to put in the newly-inserted node

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the new head of the list.

refsect2.title: g_slist_insert_sorted ()
refsect2.programlisting: GSList * g_slist_insert_sorted (GSList *list, gpointer data, GCompareFunc func);
refsect2.para: Inserts a new element into the list, using the given comparison function to determine its position.

entry.para: the data for the new element
the function to compare elements in the list. It should return a number > 0 if the first parameter comes after the second parameter in the sort order.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the new start of the GSList

refsect2.title: g_slist_remove ()
refsect2.para: Removes an element from a GSList. If two elements contain the same data, only the first is removed. If none of the elements contain the data, the GSList is unchanged.

entry.para: the data of the element to remove

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the new start of the GSList

refsect2.title: g_slist_remove_link ()
refsect2.para: Removes an element from a GSList, without freeing the element. The removed element's next link is set to NULL, so that it becomes a self-contained list with one element.

Removing arbitrary nodes from a singly-linked list requires time that is proportional to the length of the list (ie. O(n)). If you find yourself using g_slist_remove_link() frequently, you should consider a different data structure, such as the doubly-linked GList.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the new start of the GSList, without the element

refsect2.title: g_slist_delete_link ()
refsect2.para: Removes the node link_ from the list and frees it. Compare this to g_slist_remove_link() which removes the node without freeing it.

Removing arbitrary nodes from a singly-linked list requires time that is proportional to the length of the list (ie. O(n)). If you find yourself using g_slist_delete_link() frequently, you should consider a different data structure, such as the doubly-linked GList.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the new head of list

refsect2.title: g_slist_remove_all ()
refsect2.para: Removes all list nodes with data equal to data . Returns the new head of the list. Contrast with g_slist_remove() which removes only the first node matching the given data.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: new head of list

refsect2.title: g_slist_free ()
refsect2.para: Frees all of the memory used by a GSList. The freed elements are returned to the slice allocator.
If list elements contain dynamically-allocated memory, you should either use g_slist_free_full() or free them manually first.

refsect2.title: g_slist_free_full ()
refsect2.para: Convenience method, which frees all the memory used by a GSList, and calls the specified destroy function on every element's data.
free_func must not modify the list (eg, by removing the freed element from it).

entry.para: the function to be called to free each element's data

refsect2.para: Since: 2.28

refsect2.title: g_slist_free_1 ()
refsect2.para: Frees one GSList element. It is usually used after g_slist_remove_link().

refsect2.title: g_slist_length ()
refsect2.para: Gets the number of elements in a GSList.
This function iterates over the whole list to count its elements. To check whether the list is non-empty, it is faster to check list against NULL.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the number of elements in the GSList

refsect2.title: g_slist_copy ()
refsect2.para: Copies a GSList.
Note that this is a "shallow" copy. If the list elements consist of pointers to data, the pointers are copied but the actual data isn't. See g_slist_copy_deep() if you need to copy the data as well.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: a copy of list

refsect2.title: g_slist_copy_deep ()
refsect2.programlisting: GSList * g_slist_copy_deep (GSList *list, GCopyFunc func, gpointer user_data);
refsect2.para: Makes a full (deep) copy of a GSList.
In contrast with g_slist_copy(), this function uses func to make a copy of each list element, in addition to copying the list container itself.

func , as a GCopyFunc, takes two arguments, the data to be copied and a user_data pointer. On common processor architectures, it's safe to pass NULL as user_data if the copy function takes only one argument. You may get compiler warnings from this though if compiling with GCCâ€™s -Wcast-function-type warning.
For instance, if list holds a list of GObjects, you can do:
And, to entirely free the new list, you could do:

entry.para: a copy function used to copy every element in the list
user data passed to the copy function func , or NULL

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: a full copy of list , use g_slist_free_full() to free it

refsect2.para: Since: 2.34

refsect2.title: g_slist_reverse ()
refsect2.para: Reverses a GSList.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the start of the reversed GSList

refsect2.title: g_slist_insert_sorted_with_data ()
refsect2.programlisting: GSList * g_slist_insert_sorted_with_data (GSList *list, gpointer data, GCompareDataFunc func, gpointer user_data);
refsect2.para: Inserts a new element into the list, using the given comparison function to determine its position.

entry.para: the data for the new element
the function to compare elements in the list. It should return a number > 0 if the first parameter comes after the second parameter in the sort order.
data to pass to comparison function

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the new start of the GSList

refsect2.para: Since: 2.10

refsect2.title: g_slist_sort ()
refsect2.para: Sorts a GSList using the given comparison function. The algorithm used is a stable sort.

entry.para: the comparison function used to sort the GSList. This function is passed the data from 2 elements of the GSList and should return 0 if they are equal, a negative value if the first element comes before the second, or a positive value if the first element comes after the second.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the start of the sorted GSList

refsect2.title: g_slist_sort_with_data ()
refsect2.programlisting: GSList * g_slist_sort_with_data (GSList *list, GCompareDataFunc compare_func, gpointer user_data);
refsect2.para: Like g_slist_sort(), but the sort function accepts a user data argument.

entry.para: data to pass to comparison function

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: new head of the list

refsect2.title: g_slist_concat ()
refsect2.para: Adds the second GSList onto the end of the first GSList. Note that the elements of the second GSList are not copied. They are used directly.

entry.para: the GSList to add to the end of the first GSList

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the start of the new GSList

refsect2.title: g_slist_foreach ()
refsect2.programlisting: void g_slist_foreach (GSList *list, GFunc func, gpointer user_data);
refsect2.para: Calls a function for each element of a GSList.
It is safe for func to remove the element from list , but it must not modify any part of the list after that element.

entry.para: the function to call with each element's data
user data to pass to the function

refsect2.title: g_slist_last ()
refsect2.para: Gets the last element in a GSList.
This function iterates over the whole list.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the last element in the GSList, or NULL if the GSList has no elements

refsect2.title: g_slist_next()
refsect2.para: A convenience macro to get the next element in a GSList. Note that it is considered perfectly acceptable to access slist->next directly.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the next element, or NULL if there are no more elements.

refsect2.title: g_slist_nth ()
refsect2.para: Gets the element at the given position in a GSList.

entry.para: the position of the element, counting from 0

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the element, or NULL if the position is off the end of the GSList

refsect2.title: g_slist_nth_data ()
refsect2.para: Gets the data of the element at the given position.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the element's data, or NULL if the position is off the end of the GSList

refsect2.title: g_slist_find ()
refsect2.para: Finds the element in a GSList which contains the given data.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the found GSList element, or NULL if it is not found

refsect2.title: g_slist_find_custom ()
refsect2.programlisting: GSList * g_slist_find_custom (GSList *list, gconstpointer data, GCompareFunc func);
refsect2.para: Finds an element in a GSList, using a supplied function to find the desired element. It iterates over the list, calling the given function which should return 0 when the desired element is found. The function takes two gconstpointer arguments, the GSList element's data as the first argument and the given user data.

entry.para: user data passed to the function
the function to call for each element. It should return 0 when the desired element is found

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the found GSList element, or NULL if it is not found

refsect2.title: g_slist_position ()
refsect2.para: Gets the position of the given element in the GSList (starting from 0).

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the position of the element in the GSList, or -1 if the element is not found

refsect2.title: g_slist_index ()
refsect2.para: Gets the position of the element containing the given data (starting from 0).

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the index of the element containing the data, or -1 if the data is not found

refsect2.title: struct GSList
refsect2.para: The GSList struct is used for each element in the singly-linked list.

entry.para: holds the element's data, which can be a pointer to any kind of data, or any integer value using the Type Conversion Macros
contains the link to the next element in the list.

refsect2.title: g_slist_free1
refsect2.para: A macro which does the same as g_slist_free_1().
Since: 2.10
